prompt: machines are thought to work in two ways : On a high pulse rate of 90 - 130 Hz ( the normal method of use ) , the electrical impulses
watermarked_text: machines are thought to work in two ways : On a high pulse rate of 90 - 130 Hz ( the normal method of use ), the electrical impulses from the muscle stimulator are delivered to the muscles in a series of rapid,high voltage pulses, which cause the muscles to contract strongly. This type of pulsation is useful for building strength and muscle mass. On a low pulse rate of about 3 Hz ( not recommended for anyone other than athletes), the impulses are delivered continuously to the muscles. This creates an effect similar to that of isometric muscle contraction,and is useful for endurance and stamina. As an example, the squat machine typically uses a high pulse frequency for building strength, while Nordic treadmills tend to use a low pulse frequency for stamina building. It is also considered that the pulsation in some machines, perhaps unnecessarily, can be increased to values as high as 200 - 300 Hz to try to get even more strength from the muscles. Some machines also allow users to adjust the duration of the contraction phase and the rest phase between contractions, which can be a useful feature for targeting specific types of muscle fibres
unwatermarked_text:
machines are thought to work in two ways : On a high pulse rate of 90 - 130 Hz ( the normal method of use ), the electrical impulses stimulate the muscles and nerves.
There are various types & sizes of TENS machines available. The most common type is a battery - powered unit. Some have multiple channels which allow for the use of several pairs of electrodes simultaneously, whilst others have single channel devices.
The electrodes are usually made of a conductive rubber or gel-filled material and are placed on the skin in the area to be treated. The machine is adjusted so that the intensity of the electrical pulses is comfortable but not painful. The duration of treatment depends on the condition being treated, but typically 15 - 30 minutes is sufficient. Treatments can be carried out daily for as long as needed.
While TENS is generally safe and well - tolerated when used as directed, there are some contraindications. These include :
1. Implants such as pacemakers, ICDs, or neurostimulators.
2. Severe infections or inflammatory skin conditions.
3. Presence of implanted electrodes or metal fragments near the treatment site
natural_text: generated by the TENS machine interfere with and block pain messages sent to the brain . This is due to the gate control theory of pain . This proposes that there is a gate mechanism in the brain and spinal cord nerves ( the central nervous system ) . When the gate is open , pain messages get through to the brain and we feel pain . When the gate is closed , these pain messages are blocked and we do not feel pain . TENS machines are thought to stimulate certain non - pain - carrying nerves and close the gate . In effect , the brain is busy dealing with the messages it receives quickly from the TENS machine , rather than the slower ( more painful ) pain signals that the body is receiving from elsewhere . It explains why , if you injure yourself , rubbing that area can temporarily reduce the pain . When the machine is set on a low pulse rate ( 2 - 5 Hz ) it stimulates the body to make its own pain - easing chemicals called endorphins . These act a bit like morphine to block pain signals .,

Dyspraxia, also known as developmental coordination disorder (DCD), is a neurodevelopmental disorder that affects an individual's ability to plan and carry out coordinated movements. It is characterized by difficulties with motor planning, motor skill acquisition, and the execution of smooth and accurate movements. Common symptoms of dyspraxia include awkward or jerky movements, poor balance, delayed motor milestones, and difficulties with tasks that require fine motor coordination. These challenges can... Dyscalculia is a learning disorder that involves difficulties with math and numbers. It is a specific type of learning disability, and individuals with dyscalculia may struggle with basic math skills, such as understanding numbers, counting, and
natural_text: system that co - ordinate these kinds of activities develops in childhood . As a result , motor ' milestones ' , such as the age of first walking , tend to be delayed . Dyspraxia in children can also affect other activities which involve co - ordination of muscle and brain activity , including speaking , and organising complicated tasks . Dyspraxia does not affect intelligence . It does , however , place extra hurdles in the way of children during their educational years . In any group of children there is a broad range of abilities , and children develop at different rates . Children with dyspraxia are not abnormal children ; they are the group of children whose motor co - ordination is developing most slowly , so that some things are harder for them to learn . This does n't mean the skills which they find difficult can not be learned , just that children with dyspraxia will find them harder to learn than other children do . Social, emotional and psychological aspects
Children with dyspraxis often experience a range of emotions, including frustration and anger, as they struggle to carry out everyday tasks that other children find easy. They may also feel ashamed or embarrassed about their difficulties and become withdrawn. For this reason, it is especially important to build their self-esteem and provide emotional support. Behavioural therapy may also be helpful in teaching coping strategies.
In general, interventions for dyspraxic children aim to improve coordination and movement skills, as well as developing their overall strength, balance and fine motor control. Here are some ways you can help your child:

How does this affect my child in daily life?
Dyspraxia can affect your child in a number of ways, making everyday tasks more challenging. These challenges can lead to frustration and a decrease in self-esteem. Some common effects of dyspraxiainclude:
Delays in motor milestones : Your child may have difficulty with movement skills such as crawling, walking, or even tying their shoes.
Discoordinated movements : Your child might have trouble with things like stacking blocks, buttoning a shirt, or using a fork and knife. Their movements may appear awkward or jerky.
Difficulty with writing and fine motor skills : Your child likely has poor handwriting and may struggle with activities like drawing, coloring, or using scissors.

Learning a new skill requires perseverance and practice. Every time we perform the skill, connections between our nerves are strengthened, making it easier to perform the action the next time. This is why it often takes a long time to learn complex skills like playing a musical instrument or riding a bicycle. Sometimes, our nervous system may not form the connections we need to learn a skill quickly or easily. This can be due to various factors, including genes, injury, or lack of practice. #### Special Needs in Emotional Development
##### Separation Anxiety
As children grow, they often face separations, such as starting nursery school or kindergarten, or having a new baby in the family. To ensure a smoother transition, it is important to prepare them in advance. Discuss the changes that will take place and what they can expect. For younger children, avoid sudden departures and long goodbyes, as this may increase anxiety. Instead, plan a gradual separation, spending short periods of time away from each other and then returning. It is also helpful to leave a familiar object, such as a toy or blanket, with a caregiver they trust, which can provide comfort during separation. Reassure your child that you will return and that they are safe with the caregiver. Sending regular updates or photos can also help

Others rely on random sampling and hope that these characteristics are naturally represented in the sample. The choice between the two approaches can affect the results.

natural_text: most commonly after a fractured skull caused by a head injury . The fractured skull bone can cause separation of the dura mater from the inside of the skull and can cause damage to a blood vessel ( usually an artery ) . The damaged blood vessel causes blood to leak and collect in the potential epidural space between the skull and the dura mater . This build - up of blood can cause the pressure inside the head to rise . This can put pressure on the brain and cause injury to the brain if it is not treated quickly . Typically , an extradural haematoma is caused by a severe head injury - for example , in a road traffic accident . The blood usually collects in the epidural space soon after a head injury and symptoms of an extradural haematoma are usually noticed quickly . So , most extradural haematomas are ' acute ' injuries . Occasionally , bleeding can occur more slowly and an extradural haematoma may cause few symptoms ( and so not be noticed ) until some days after a head injury . The rest of this leaflet just discusses intracranial extradural haematoma .,

natural_text: , surgery is generally needed to treat a large intracranial extradural haematoma . This is usually carried out by a neurosurgeon and involves removal of the haematoma . Most commonly , surgery either involves making ' burr holes ' in the skull or an operation called a craniotomy . Burr holes are small holes that are drilled through the skull over the area where the haematoma has formed . They allow the blood to be removed , or ' sucked out ' , through the holes . Stitches or staples are then used to close the burr holes . A craniotomy is a procedure in which a portion of the skull is removed so that the brain and meninges are exposed . It can relieve any raised pressure inside the skull and also means that the clotting blood in the extradural space can be removed . The section of skull that was removed is then replaced and fixed back in place , re - attaching the outer protective lining that covers the brain ( the dura mater ) to the skull bone . Close follow - up is needed after the operation , usually in an intensive care unit .,

through the skin to an internal implant inside the cochlea. This implant allows the hearing nerve to be stimulated despite the fact that the cochlear cells are damaged. The cochlear implant receives audio signals from a sound processor and converts them into electrical signals.
A cochlear implant is a small, multi-component device that includes:
  1. A sound processor : This is typically a digital device that captures sound from the environment and converts it into electrical signals.
  2. A transmitting coil : This coil is worn behind the ear and transmits the electrical signals from the sound processor to the implant.
  3. A receiver/stimulator : This component is surgically implanted within the skull, usually behind the ear. It receives the electrical signals and sends them directly to the auditory nerve, bypassing the damaged cochlear cells.
  4. Electrodes : These fine wires are placed within the cochlea and deliver the electrical signals to specific points, which stimulate the auditory nerve.
  5. Battery : Some implants have a built-in battery, while others require an external power source.

natural_text: Antibodies are small proteins that circulate in the bloodstream . They are part of the body 's defence ( immune ) system and are sometimes called immunoglobulins . They are made by B lymphocytes - a type of white blood cell . The IgA gets to the kidneys in the bloodstream and then causes scarring and inflammation in the kidney . The scarring and inflammation are very small and can only be seen with a microscope . The glomeruli are damaged by deposits of IgA. IgA nephropathy does not usually run in families , so you need not worry about passing it on to your children . The cause of IgA nephropathy is not completely understood . IgA is produced by glands around the throat and bowel to fight off infection . IgA is normally two antibody molecules stuck together . In IgA nephropathy , these molecules appear to get joined up in longer chains . As these travel around in the blood and pass through the kidney they get stuck in the filters ( glomeruli ) in the kidney . The trapped IgA then causes an inflammatory reaction . It is not known why these IgA chains develop .,

These are usually harmless and are not passed on by sexual contact . However , these bacteria sometimes cause PID . Rheumatic heart disease is a general term which means any heart problem which develops after having rheumatic fever. Rheumatic fever most commonly affects the mitral valve and the aortic valve. Common symptoms may include shortness of breath, fatigue, chest pain, palpitations or feeling faint. If left untreated, rheumatic fever can lead to complications such as infective endocarditis, heart valve blockage, or even heart failure. Medical history, physical examination, and echocardiogram are commonly used to diagnose the condition. The treatment for most cases involves taking antibiotics, especially during episodes of rheumatic fever, and in some cases, surgical repair or replacement of the affected valves may be necessary. Maintaining good dental hygiene and regular visits to healthcare professionals can help prevent the spread of streptococcal infections and subsequent development of rheumatic heart disease. Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 22nd edition, Page 422. Most, but not all, people who experience rheumatic fever develop some form of heart disease. Rheumatic fever commonly affects the hearts valves, particularly the mitral valve and the aortic valve. As a result, blood can leak backward, leading to problems like heart failure, irregular heartbeats, and blood clots. The long-term effects of rheumatic fever on the heart can be serious, potentially leading to heart failure or other complications. Early recognition and treatment of rheumatic heart disease are crucial to prevent further damage to the heart and its valves. Management of the condition includes medication to reduce inflammation and antibiotics to prevent recurrent infection. In some cases, surgical intervention, such as valve repair or replacement, may be necessary to restore proper heart function. In systemic sclerosis , the immune system damages the connective tissue cells , which are found in many parts of the body . Your connective tissue supports , binds or separates other tissues and organs within your body and can also be a kind of packing tissue in your body . So , systemic sclerosis is also classed as a connective tissue disease . It is not known what triggers the immune system to cause systemic sclerosis . There is probably an inherited tendency to develop it . It is more common in people who have a family member with systemic sclerosis . It may be triggered by certain germs ( such as viruses ) , medicines , street drugs and chemicals . A number of different influences seem to be involved . What is known is that cells called fibroblasts are affected by the immune system in some way and make too much of a protein called collagen . The collagen gets deposited in skin , blood vessels and organs . This causes scarring and thickening ( fibrosis ) . Blood vessels are also damaged .,

What disorder involves excessive concern with body appearance and preoccupation with defects that may be slight or imagined?
Body Dysmorphic disorder ( BDD) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by an excessive and persistent concern with an imagined or slight defect in one's physical appearance. People with this disorder may focus on a physical defect that others cannot see or have a mild physical flaw that they find distressing. The concern about the defect can lead to significant impairment in social and occupational functioning. Treatment for BDD typically involves a combination of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacotherapy. In CBT, individuals learn to recognize and challenge negative thoughts about their appearance and develop healthier coping strategies. Medications such as antidepressants, particularly selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), may be prescribed to help reduce symptoms of anxiety and depression associated with BDD. It

Chemical messengers in the body
Hormones are chemical messengers in our body that are produced by different glands. They are carried through the bloodstream to reach their target cells and tissues, where they exert their functions. Ebola virus can stay in semen for up to seven weeks after the infected person has recovered . The Ebola epidemic was declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) in August 2014 by the World Health Organization (WHO) due to its unprecedented size and the high risk of international spread. Efforts to control the outbreak involved various strategies such as contact tracing, infection control, safe burials, health education, and the deployment of medical teams and supplies. natural_text: Lymph glands ( also called lymph nodes ) occur throughout the body . They are normally pea - sized . They are a major part of the body 's defence ( immune ) system . During an infection , lymph glands swell and become painful while the immune system fights off infecting germs . They go back to normal after the infection is over . Most people are familiar with lymph glands in the neck that can swell when you have a sore throat or tonsillitis . In a similar way , it is the lymph glands in the tummy , next to the gut ( intestine ) , that swell during a bout of mesenteric adenitis . ( See separate leaflet called Swollen Lymph Glands for more about lymph glands . ) Probably , a germ ( infection ) triggers the inflammation and swelling in the lymph glands . Most cases are probably due to a viral infection . Less often , it may be a bacterial infection that is the cause - for example , a bacterial infection in the intestine . The inflamed glands then cause pain , tenderness and a high temperature ( fever ) .,

One method of cardioversion is to give your heart a shock using a device called a defibrillator. Another method is to give medication to stop your heart and then restart it with an electric shock. Once your heart is back to a regular rhythm, your doctor will prescribe medication to keep it that way. This medication is like a maintenance program for your heart and prevents your heartbeat from going back to its irregular rhythm again. This is why it's called antiarrhythmic medication. Your doctor will also monitor your heart to make sure the medication is working correctly and will make adjustments if needed. So, treatment for an irregular heartbeat includes both rhythm control to get your heart back to a steady rhythm and medication to keep your heart in that rhythm and prevent future arrhythmias.

What is high blood pressure (hypertension)?
High blood pressure means that the force of your blood against the walls of your arteries is consistently too high. This increases your risk of health problems such as heart disease, stroke, and kidney disease. It often has no symptoms, hence its nickname the'silent killer'.

High blood pressure is diagnosed with a blood pressure test, often referred to as a sphygmomanometer reading. It measures two numbers: systolic (the top number) and diastolic (the bottom number). A result of 130/80mmHg or higher is considered high blood pressure.

What is the role of red bone marrow in adults?
Red bone marrow plays a crucial role in the formation of new blood cells. In adults, it is responsible for the production of red blood cells ( erythrocytes ), white blood cells ( leukocytes ), and platelets ( thrombocytes ). It is the site of blood cell formation, known as hematopoiesis.

Yes, adult bone marrow does produce different types and stages of blood cells. It is responsible for producing all types of blood cell including red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. Each cell type undergoes different stages of development in the bone marrow before being released into the bloodstream.

However , it is thought that a tiny part of the infecting germ and tiny parts of nerves in the body have similar structures . In some people , the antibodies that attack the germ also mistake the nerves as germs . So , the antibodies also attach to , and damage , the nerves , causing inflammation of the nerves and leading to GBS . If a nerve is damaged then the muscles which the nerve supplies stop working . Note : there are various other autoimmune diseases . Most tend to run a persistent ( chronic ) course once the immune system is triggered - for example , rheumatoid arthritis . However , GBS is different in that the disease activity seems to be time - limited . That is , the immune system reacts to a recent infection which can cause nerve damage , but then settles down again . This is why most people with GBS recover fully .,

Examples include : Relaxed, slow, deep breathing : breathe in gently through your nose and breathe out through your mouth. Pursed lip breathing : hold your breath for a few seconds after breathing in, then breathe out slowly through pursed lips, as if you're blowing out a candle. Diaphragmatic breathing : lie on your back with one hand on your chest and the other on your abdomen. Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose, feeling the hand on your abdomen move outwards as you breathe in. Then breathe out slowly though your mouth while feeling your abdomen move inwards. Singing or humming : This can help to keep your airways open. Remember to take regular breaks when doing any of these breathing exercises, and if you find them hard to do at first, practice them at home with the help of a respiratory therapist. It may also be helpful to learn relaxation techniques, such as progressive muscular relaxation or guided imagery, to help manage stress and anxiety that can contribute to breathlessness. Remember to consult your healthcare provider or a respiratory therapist for personalized advice on managing your breathlessness

Examples include : Relaxed, slow, deep breathing : breathe in gently through your nose and breathe out through your mouth. Pursed-lip breathing : breathe out through pursed lips as if blowing out a candle. This technique helps to slow down your breathing and can help to keep your airways open. Inspiratory hold technique or “holding your breath” : take a slow breath in and then hold your breath for a few seconds before exhaling. This technique can help to fill your lungs with more air and may reduce the feeling of breathlessness. These techniques can be used together with certain medications to help manage your breathlessness. You should discuss these techniques with your healthcare provider to determine which one works best for you. Managing breathlessness during physical activity is also important, and your healthcare provider or respiratory therapist can provide guidance on how to pace yourself and plan your activities accordingly. Breathing exercises can be particularly useful during episodes of breathlessness, before and after exercise, and when lying flat. It is important to remember that while these breathing techniques can help relieve breathlessness, they may not eliminate it completely.

watermarked_text:
impulse gets to the atrioventricular node ( AV node ) at the lower right atrium. This acts like a'junction box'and the impulse is delayed slightly (approximately 0.1 seconds) before passing down the bundle of His and its branches to the ventricles. The impulse is then rapidly distributed throughout the ventricular myocardium via the network of Purkinje fibers, resulting in the depolarization of the ventricLES. It is only when the impulse reaches the ventricLes that the atria cease to contract, because the impulse does not retraverse the atrio-ventricular node. Thus, the atria have effectively finished contracting before the ventric LES.
In summary, the sequence of contraction of the cardiac chambers is as follows: 1. Atrial depolarization (P wave on ECG), 2. Atrial contraction (t wave on EGC), 3. Delay in AV node, 4. Ventricular depolarization, and 5. Ventricular contraction. The ventricles contract only after the atria complete their contraction.

natural_text: . Most of the tissue between the atria and ventricles does not conduct the impulse . However , a thin band of conducting fibres called the atrioventricular bundle ( AV bundle ) acts like ' wires ' and carries the impulse from the AV node to the ventricles . The AV bundle splits into two - a right and a left branch . These then split into many tiny fibres ( the Purkinje system ) which conduct the electrical impulse throughout the ventricles . This makes the ventricles contract and pump blood through one - way valves into large arteries : The artery going from the right ventricle ( pulmonary artery ) takes blood to the lungs . The artery going from the left ventricle ( aorta ) takes blood to the rest of the body . The heart then rests for a short time ( diastole ) . Blood coming back to the heart from the large veins fills the atria during diastole : The veins coming into the left atria bring blood from the lungs ( full of oxygen ) . The veins coming into the right atria bring blood from the body ( needing oxygen ) .,
